SENT.plain: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE: Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) and Angelman syndrome (AS) are caused by deficiencies of gene expression from paternal or maternal chromosome 15q11-q13, respectively
The study was conducted to estimate the prevalence of PWS and AS in children with moderate to profound mental retardation in Taiwan
METHODS: The screening began with methylation studies in all enrolled cases

If methylation results were positive, Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was used to determine whether deletion, uniparental disomy, or imprinting mutation was present
RESULTS: Of 1053 children with moderate to profound mental retardation, we identified three cases of AS (0.28%) and one case of PWS (0.09%)
CONCLUSIONS: The prevalence of PWS is lower than AS in school children with moderate to profound mental retardation
The greater number of AS identified than that of PWS is most likely a reflection of more severe mental retardation for AS than for PWS
